awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Advanced Three-dimensional Flow Measurement System
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art three-dimensional flow measurement system to enhance Purdue Northwest's capacity to conduct fundamental research and foster multidisciplinary research collaborations, including those with regional industries.   The award will give faculty and more than 50 undergraduate and graduate students-- particularly female and first-generation university students-- access to state-of-the art instrumentation. The research will provide new knowledge leading to advances in renewable energy, regenerative medicine and the development of micro air vehicles.

The instrumentation will serve as a catalyst for fundamental research on complex flows. Flow phenomena are fundamental to a range of important multidisciplinary research problems including turbulence, bio-fluid mechanics, and wind energy. These phenomena are naturally three-dimensional with complexities that previous flow measurement techniques, such as digital PIV, were unable to resolve.  The instrumentation's particle tracking capabilities allow complex three-dimensional flow to be measured and characterized with high spatial resolution and accuracy. This will enable the researchers to gain a new understanding of three-dimensional fundamental flow physics, such as the lift generation/augmentation mechanisms in flapping flight.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Utilizing the acquired Shake-The-Box system, we investigated the volumetric flow field on different objects, including the flapping wings of insects, a cylindrical water ladle model and a displacement disk of a beta type stirling engine model, under three different projects.

On a tethered housefly, the Shake-The-Box system is implemented to quantify the volumetric flow field in the wake of the flapping wings of the tethered housefly. The flow meamesurement result suggests that the volumetric flow field is symmetric between the left and right but significantly asymmetrical/different between up- and down-stroke. Meanwhile, the measurement results is utilized to compare the path-averaged velocity field that is derived from the schlieren photograhy and optical flow method, presenting a good agreement. 

To study the disturbed flow field of a gas stirred water ladle, a cylindrical water ladle model is built, and the refractive index match is implemented. The volumetric flow field inside a 6 cm x 6 cm x 2 cm domain is resolved under eight different gas stirred conditions. The flow measurement results indicate the flow inside the water ladle model is organized under low gas injection flow rate but disorganized/potentially turbulent under high gas injection flow rate and the thresh hold of the flow pattern transition is acquired. On the other hand, the volumetric flow measurement result is utilized to validate a CFD simulation model and helped us to identify an accurate turbulence model that can match with experimental results.

Moreover, the complex flow field around an oscilating disk inside a concealed cylindrical container, simulating the displacement disk of a beta type stirling engine,is investigated under the project. The measured volumetric flow result suggests that a ring of high speed jet is created when the disk moves to Top-Dead-Center as the disk squeeze the fluid above it and the jet impinges at the bottom surface of the container where the heat transfer would take place in a real stirling engine. Using the acquired flow field data, the magniutde of the jet is calcuated and the convective heat transfer coefficient is estimated accordingly.

On the other hand, the acquired instrument is effectively utlized in developing undergraduate and graduate engineering curriculum. One undergraduate fluid mechanics lab and four graduate course (Intro to aerodynamics) projects were developed and influenced 60+ undergraduate and gradaute students. Moreover, three gradaute and one PhD students were trained to utilize the acquired instrument for their thesis research. So far, One Journal and one conference papers have been published and two conference papers have been accepted. Four conference presentations have been given through this project with more publications under preparation.


Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Yun Liu

    Stirling engine displacer project

Utilizing the acquired Shake-The-Box system, we investigated the volumetric flow field on different objects, including the flapping wings of insects, a cylindrical water ladle model and a displacement disk of a beta type stirling engine model, under three different projects.
